prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for taking my 3yo out to do something fun whilst my partner is at work?
I will try and keep this short . 

Almost every weekend when I say lets take our kid out to the play centre or a farm ect I get one of maybe 3  excuses every time without fail . Either "I dont want to go out / I just wanna sit and play on the computer. " " ive been at work im tired I don't wanna go out / drive " or " I don't wanna spend the money on x, y ,z" ( we have money so its not like thats a real problem )   

Today a friend asked me if i wanted to go with her with the kids to the farm near us tomorrow and I said yes . I figured since we hadn't taken little one anywhere fun for a few weeks it would be nice . 

So I mentioned it to my partner and he goes off on one about how its not fair as he is at work and he would like to go blah blah . I said so I cant take her anywhere when you're at work ? Pointed out that I asked to go not a week or two earlier and was told no its too expencive and  I dont want to go out I'm tired. ( its £7 each ). 

So now he wants me to cancle with my friend so he can go another day . I said we can go whenever you want . But apparently thats not an option either . 

Its a childrens petting zoo ffs its not like im going to see a movie wothout him. 
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for taking their 3-year-old out for fun while their partner is at work. Let's look at the situation step by step.

First, the author mentions that every weekend they suggest going to places like a play center or a farm, but the partner always gives the same excuses: not wanting to go out, being tired from work, not wanting to spend money. The author notes that they have the money, so it's not a real problem. 

Then, the author's friend invited them to take the kids to a farm, which they agreed to. When they told the partner, the partner got upset and wanted to cancel so he could go. The author is now saying that if the partner wants to go, they can go whenever he wants, but that's not an option. The author is frustrated because the partner's excuses are recurring, and this time they took the initiative to do something fun without waiting for the partner.

So, the core issue here is about shared responsibility in childcare and decision-making. The author is trying to do something positive for their child and themselves, but the partner is resistant. The author is acting on their own because the partner has consistently been uninterested. The partner is now upset that the author went ahead without him. 

Is the author wrong? Well, the parent is making an effort to provide a fun activity for the child, especially when the other parent is unavailable. The partner's excuses seem to be habitual and possibly dismissive of the child's needs. The author isn't excluding the partner out of spite but because previous attempts to involve him were met with resistance. The cost is minimal (£7), so money isn't the real issue. The key here is whether the author overstepped by not discussing it first. However, the author tried to take the partner's previous excuses into account and chose to act in the child's best interest. The partner's reaction seems more about feeling left out or not being consulted, but if he's consistently uninterested, maybe the author is justified in making the decision independently. 

Therefore, the author isn't in the wrong. They're prioritizing the child's well-being and their own time, given the partner's repeated reluctance. The partner needs to be more supportive and perhaps find a way to be involved if that's a priority. So the answer would be B.
